Mr. BEILCOURT. For reasons which I am not going ,to discuss, it appears that the majority of the members of this House think that the time has arrived when the provisions of the Act of 1875 shall be chang— ed. Some of us think it might be changed in a broader sense, while others think it might be changed in a more restrictive sense. Whatever of that there has been a compro- mise: the majority in this House have agreed that the legislation of 1875 is not the legislation which should govern in the Ter— ritories to-day. .I say then, that we have a perfect right under the constitution and under the provisions of the Act of 1871 to enact for these Territories which are still under our jurisdiction, Territories over which no other jurisdiction exists, I say we have the power to crystallize by a separate enactment 01' as we are now doing as part of this measure the provisions of section 16 of this Bill, and these provisions would be in existence when these two provinces come into the union on the ﬁrst of July next. In other words, we have the right to deter— mine to-day what shall be the law in refer- ence to education in the Northwest Terri- tories. We have now the right and power to repeal or modify the provisions of the law of 1875 as to education.
